column1: “Box breathing is a technique that helps you take control of your automatic breathing patterns to train your breath for optimal health and performance,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Nazish, Noma. 2019. “How To De-Stress In 5 Minutes Or Less, According To A Navy SEAL.” Forbes. May 30, 2019.

column1: “The calming and focusing effects of this technique are noticeable within just a few minutes of practice,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Nazish, Noma. 2019. “How To De-Stress In 5 Minutes Or Less, According To A Navy SEAL.” Forbes. May 30, 2019.

column1: “Box breathing allowed me to perform exceedingly well in the SEALs,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Nazish, Noma. 2019. “How To De-Stress In 5 Minutes Or Less, According To A Navy SEAL.” Forbes. May 30, 2019.

column1: “[Box breathing] was instrumental in saving my life several times in crises,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Nazish, Noma. 2019. “How To De-Stress In 5 Minutes Or Less, According To A Navy SEAL.” Forbes. May 30, 2019.

column1: “[Stress] suppresses the immune system, increasing susceptibility to colds and other illnesses,”
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2015. “Relaxation Techniques: Breath Control Helps Quell Errant Stress Response.” Harvard Health. January 2015.

column1: “[Focused breathing can arouse] increased comfort, relaxation, pleasantness, vigor and alertness, and reduced symptoms of arousal, anxiety, depression, anger, and confusion,”
column4: Zaccaro, Andrea, Andrea Piarulli, Marco Laurino, Erika Garbella, Danilo Menicucci, Bruno Neri, and Angelo Gemignani. 2018. “How Breath-Control Can Change Your Life: A Systematic Review on Psycho-Physiological Correlates of Slow Breathing.” Frontiers in Human Neuroscience 12 (September). https://doi.org/10.3389/fnhum.2018.00353.

column1: “When you hold your breath, do not clamp down and create back pressure. Rather, maintain an expansive, open feeling even though you are not inhaling,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Divine, Mark. 2016. “A Navy Seal Breathing Technique to Stay Calm and Focused.” Time. May 4, 2016.

column1: “Breathing has both an involuntary control mechanism as well as voluntary; it can shift between being piloted and being left on autopilot,”
column3: Former US Navy SEALs Commander, NYT bestselling author, Founder of SEALFIT.
column4: Divine, Mark. 2016. “A Navy Seal Breathing Technique to Stay Calm and Focused.” Time. May 4, 2016.

column1: “When our phone battery goes from green to red, we immediately stop and recharge. But when our own bodies go into the red zone, we push through. Living in the red zone means living in a zone of depletion where we’re more susceptible to burnout, anxiety, or depression,”
column3: Coauthor of The 5-Minute Recharge: 31 Proven Strategies to Refresh, Reset, and Become the Boss of Your Day.
column4: Vozza, Stephanie. 2019. “These Navy SEAL Tricks Will Help You Perform Better under Pressure.” Fast Company. May 25, 2019.

column1: “Meditation is a good way to increase mindfulness in your whole life. Mindfulness is a concept that sprang from Buddhism originally... it means the practice of purposely focusing your attention on the present moment—and accepting it without judgment,”
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “Thoughts may enter the mind. This is natural. Simply allow them to arise and pass,”
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “If a chain of thought hijacks your attention and you lose awareness of the breath, gently return your attention to the sensations of breathing,”
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “Simply observing the breath can damp down stress and open a door to a more healthy and mindful lifestyle,”
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “Many people take up mindfulness practices thinking they'd like to relax more, but where it leads is a very different approach to life and its inevitable challenges,”
column3: Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychology at Harvard Medical School.
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “Learning to focus attention and relax is a skill. As with any skill, your ability to focus and relax will improve with practice,”
column3: Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychology at Harvard Medical School.
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.

column1: “Ultimately, most of our stress comes from fighting reality,”
column3: Assistant Clinical Professor of Psychology at Harvard Medical School.
column4: Publishing, Harvard Health. 2014. “Breath Meditation: A Great Way to Relieve Stress.” Harvard Health. April 2014.
